perturbation.original_text:
Neither the Franchisor, its Predecessor nor any person listed under Item 2 or an affiliate offering franchises under Franchisor’s principal
trademark:


(A)
has an administrative, criminal or civil action pending against that person alleging: a felony; a violation of a franchise,
antitrust or securities law; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion; misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive
practices; or comparable civil or misdemeanor allegations.
perturbation.changed_text:
Neither the Franchisor, its Predecessor nor any person listed under Item 2 or an affiliate offering franchises under Franchisor’s principal
trademark:


(A)
has an administrative, criminal or civil action pending against that person alleging: a felony; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion; misappropriation of property; or comparable civil or misdemeanor allegations.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'a violation of a franchise, antitrust or securities law' from the list of allegations that must be disclosed, the contract becomes non-compliant with New York franchise law, which requires full disclosure of any pending actions related to these areas. This omission misleads potential franchisees by concealing potentially material information about the franchisor's legal history.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York Franchise Law, Article 33 of the General Business Law

perturbation.original_text:
(B)
has been convicted of a felony or pleaded nolo contendere to a felony charge or, within the ten year period immediately
preceding the application for registration, has been convicted of or pleaded nolo contendere to a misdemeanor charge or has
been the subject of a civil action alleging: violation of a franchise; anti-fraud or securities law; fraud; embezzlement;
fraudulent conversion or misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive practices; or comparable allegations.
perturbation.changed_text:
(B)
has been convicted of a felony or pleaded nolo contendere to a felony charge or, within the ten year period immediately
preceding the application for registration, has been convicted of or pleaded nolo contendere to a misdemeanor charge or has
been the subject of a civil action alleging: fraud; embezzlement;
fraudulent conversion or misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive practices; or comparable allegations.
perturbation.explanation: By omitting 'violation of a franchise; anti-fraud or securities law' from the list of disclosable civil actions, this change introduces a significant legal risk. New York franchise law mandates the disclosure of such actions to protect potential franchisees. This omission reduces transparency and potentially misleads franchisees.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York Franchise Law, Article 33 of the General Business Law

perturbation.original_text:
Neither the Franchisor, its affiliate, its predecessor, officers, or general partner during the ten year period immediately before the date of
the disclosure document: (a) filed as debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (or any
comparable foreign law); (b) obtained a discharge of its debts under the bankruptcy code; or (c) was a principal officer of a company or a general
partner in a partnership that either filed as a debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or that
obtained a discharge of its debts under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code during or within one year after the officer or general partner of the Franchisor
held this position in the company or partnership.
perturbation.changed_text:
Neither the Franchisor, its affiliate, its predecessor, officers, or general partner during the five year period immediately before the date of
the disclosure document: (a) filed as debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (or any
comparable foreign law); (b) obtained a discharge of its debts under the bankruptcy code; or (c) was a principal officer of a company or a general
partner in a partnership that either filed as a debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or that
obtained a discharge of its debts under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code during or within one year after the officer or general partner of the Franchisor
held this position in the company or partnership.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the look-back period for bankruptcy disclosures from ten years to five years constitutes an omission of material information required by New York franchise law. This makes the contract non-compliant as it withholds information that could significantly impact a franchisee's decision.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York Franchise Law, Article 33 of the General Business Law
